sub_topic: Finding the area between two curves using integration
message_1: Find the area enclosed between two curves y = x² and y = 4 - x² using integration.
message_2:
To find the area enclosed between the two curves y = x² and y = 4 - x², we first need to find the points of intersection. We can do this by setting the two equations equal to each other:

x² = 4 - x²

2x² = 4
x² = 2
x = ±√2

So the points of intersection are at x = -√2 and x = √2. Now we can set up the integral to find the area between the curves. The area will be the integral of the difference between the two functions from -√2 to √2:

Area = ∫[-√2, √2] (4 - x² - x²) dx

Simplify the integrand:

Area = ∫[-√2, √2] (4 - 2x²) dx

Now, integrate the function with respect to x:

Area = [4x - (2/3)x³] (from -√2 to √2)

Evaluate the integral at the limits of integration:

Area = (4√2 - (2/3)(√2)³) - (4(-√2) - (2/3)(-√2)³)
Area = (4√2 - (8/3)(2)) - (-4√2 - (8/3)(-2))
Area = (4√2 - 16/3) - (-4√2 + 16/3)
Area = 4√2 - 16/3 + 4√2 - 16/3
Area = 8√2 - 32/3

So the area enclosed between the two curves y = x² and y = 4 - x² is 8√2 - 32/3 square units.
